stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on implementing and debugging several new, complex star select screens designed by Biobak. This involved importing models, solving a frustrating compiler bug with a sine wave function, fixing graphical artifacts on a lighting effect through live collaboration, and programming intricate animations for a submarine and a bird.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refines the intro cutscene for the Oll-Black boss based on a viewer's suggestion, deciding to have the boss spit Mario across the arena.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, you know what maybe after he comes out of here we just have an animation of him spitting out Mario and Mario goes and lands over here. I think I'll do that. That is a good call.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spends a significant amount of time debugging an erratic sine wave animation, eventually discovering the cause was a missing '#include <math.h>' in his C file, which led the GCC compiler to link to garbage data without issuing a warning.
development_findings.quote: What the fuck how can it just link garbage data and not tell me? What even did it link?

development_findings.summary: Kaze fixed a visual artifact on a volumetric light model by remodeling the geometry with more vertices to create a smoother gradient, after collaborating with Biobak to identify the issue was vertex shading.
Kaze identifies a core engine limitation where object animations freeze during the level transition fadeout. He defers the proper fix, which requires a deeper engine change, for a later time.
development_findings.quote: I just need to make it so that while the fadeout is happening, the animation is actually playing. Because right now the animation just freezes while the fadeout is happening and that's a big deal.

development_findings.summary: The game's overworld is planned to be completely redesigned with a tropical island theme, an idea inspired by playing Mario Party.
development_findings.quote: We were playing Mario Party. And I'm thinking we should theme the island for the overworld like this. You know, tropical island.

development_findings.summary: Kaze reveals a design guideline that every star in the game is placed exactly 200 units above the floor, while item boxes are 300 units high.
Kaze and the chat brainstorm future level themes. He is enthusiastic about a Wild West level and considers a comic/superhero or arctic/ice cream level, while rejecting a music-themed level.
The planned 'Retro Sections' are revealed to be based on Paper Mario 64, Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, Mario Land 1, and Smash 64, though Kaze is open to changing them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a core philosophy of needing to understand the root cause of a problem rather than just accepting a surface-level fix.
context_findings.quote: You can't just be like, oh it works good enough. You have to be like why the fuck is it not doing what I expect to do?

context_findings.summary: Kaze wants his work to be judged independently of his personal identity, showing a pragmatic awareness of online culture and a desire for the game to have its own life.
context_findings.quote: The player shouldn't even know that I exist when he plays this game. That way, if in the future I get cancelled on Twitter, no one has to put down the game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina are moving to a new house the day after the stream. He mentions he will have a week off from his day job and will be streaming from his new 'dungeon'.
Kaze mentions he does not have children yet but plans to one day, indicating a long-term personal outlook.
context_findings.quote: I haven't played Mario Wonder, I'm planning to play it with my kids in like 5 years or something. I don't know.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided multiple complex 3D models for the star select screens, including a submarine, volumetric lights, and an animated bird.
Biobak gives specific animation feedback through chat, guiding Kaze on implementing the intended motion for the submarine model.
biobak.quote: Your Waves are the same speed Biobak. What did you mean by one of them is slowed down by 0.5? Did you maybe mean that one of them was offset by 0.5?

biobak.summary: Kaze and Biobak collaborate on the cloud animations for a star select screen, with Kaze initially misinterpreting Biobak's silence as disapproval before clarifying and proceeding.
biobak.quote: I asked you if I should do this and you didn't respond. So I thought, oh, maybe he doesn't want me.

zeina.summary: Zeina humorously recalls a character from a previous hack, 'Donkey Donkey Mario 64', indicating a shared history and casual, supportive dynamic with Kaze's creative projects.
zeina.quote: I think I'm still slightly traumatized from the weeb toad.

key_stories.title: The Mysterious Sine Wave Compiler Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled with a bizarre bug causing an object to move erratically. After extensive debugging, he found the cause was not his code but a silent compiler failure due to a missing header file, a frustrating but insightful technical problem.
key_stories.challenge: A submarine model, meant to animate in a smooth sine wave for a star select screen, was moving erratically and unpredictably.
key_stories.process: Kaze debugged the issue for a long time by printing values, checking data types, and questioning his math. After ruling out logical errors in his code, he correctly suspected a deeper compiler or linking issue.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze discovered the C file was missing the required '#include <math.h>' header. The GCC compiler, instead of erroring, silently linked the sine function to garbage memory. Adding the include instantly fixed the bug, serving as a lesson in compiler quirks.
key_stories.key_quote: I think what happened is that the compiler just linked garbage data somehow. What the fuck how can it just link garbage data and not tell me?

key_stories.title: Fixing the Volumetric Light Artifacts
key_stories.summary: A key visual effect for a level had ugly graphical artifacts. Through real-time collaboration, Kaze and Biobak identified the cause as a vertex shading issue on the 3D model, which Kaze then fixed by remodeling the asset live on stream.
key_stories.challenge: A volumetric light effect created by Biobak was rendering with severe color banding and an ugly 'X' shaped artifact in the center.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Biobak diagnosed the problem live in the stream chat. After ruling out texture issues, they identified the cause as vertex shading on a low-poly model. Kaze then live-prototyped a new model with a higher polygon count to solve the issue.
key_stories.outcome: By remodeling the light cone with more vertices, Kaze was able to create a smoother color gradient that eliminated the artifact, successfully translating Biobak's artistic vision into the game engine.
key_stories.key_quote: I shaded black, but if you don't shade them black, then it just looks like a blurry circle. Yeah, I removed that by having more of them.

key_stories.title: The Freezing Bird on Level Exit
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered that a bird's take-off animation was freezing due to a core engine behavior during level transitions. He diagnosed the root cause and decided to postpone the complex engine-level fix, highlighting the practical trade-offs in game development.
key_stories.challenge: An animated bird on a star select screen needed to fly away when a level was selected, but its animation froze during the screen's fade-out transition.
key_stories.process: Kaze implemented the bird's idle and take-off animations. Upon testing the take-off, he immediately noticed it froze. He quickly diagnosed that the game's engine pauses object updates during the level transition sequence.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a temporary solution to make the transition look acceptable but acknowledged the proper fix requires modifying the engine's core update loop. He deferred this larger task, illustrating the process of prioritizing development and distinguishing between temporary workarounds and long-term solutions.
key_stories.key_quote: I just need to make it so that while the fadeout is happening, the animation is actually playing. Because right now the animation just freezes... and that's a big deal.

open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly states that the stream's intended goal was to work on the 'Oll-Black Boss', but he was sidetracked by implementing Biobak's star select screens. He mentions most of the work on the boss has been done off-stream.
questions: What is the core concept and gameplay mechanic for the Oll-Black boss fight?
What specific progress has been made on the boss off-stream?
What are the biggest remaining technical or design challenges to completing it?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that the entire overworld will be scrapped and redesigned based on a tropical island theme inspired by a Mario Party board.
questions: Which Mario Party game or board specifically inspired this new direction?
What are the key design goals for the new overworld in terms of player progression and exploration?
How will you handle navigation and potential fast-travel in this new, single-island layout?

open_questions.context: During a conversation, it's revealed that a character in a previous hack was inspired by community member Skellux. Kaze seemed unaware of this lore, and Lilaa, who brought it up, refused to elaborate.
questions: What is the story behind the pink bob-omb in 'Donkey Donkey Mario 64' being inspired by Skellux?
How often are characters or inside jokes from the community integrated into the games?
Can you share another example of a community-inspired element in your work?

open_questions.context: Kaze is trying to implement an animation for a bird flying away, but it freezes because the engine stops updating objects during the level transition fadeout.
questions: You identified that the engine freezes object updates during fades. What is the process for fixing a deep issue like that?
How do you decide when to implement a 'dirty' workaround versus stopping to fix a core engine problem?
Does the Mario 64 decompilation project make it easier to tackle these kinds of fundamental engine changes compared to traditional ROM hacking?
